Developments in five areas will determine if the industry is about to blossom.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2Fca%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Flocations%2Fnorth%20america%2Fcanada%2Four%20insights%2Fspringtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry%2Fspringtime-for-canadas-fintech-industry.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="springtime-for-canadas-fintech-industry" data-layer-report-name="springtime-for-canadas-fintech-industry>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (13 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>Canada’s financial-services industry</strong> seems to be a textbook case of an industry primed for disruption by fintech.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="Expandable Sidebar" type="button" id="button_id" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__toggle-btn__EL8iE" aria-expanded="false" data-layer-event-prefix="UI Item" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-category="sidebar" data-layer-subcategory="open" data-layer-text="open sidebar"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This report is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/federico-berruti">Federico Berruti</a>, <a href="/our-people/miklos-dietz">Miklós Dietz</a>, <a href="/our-people/uzayr-jeenah">Uzayr Jeenah</a>, Opeyemi Otubela, Emily Seng Yue, and Ammar Zahid, representing views from McKinsey’s Financial Services Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>First, its banking industry is large compared with other G-7 countries. Banking revenues of $180 billion accounted for 7.9 percent of GDP in 2023, compared with 5.8 percent in the United States and an average of 5.6 percent among other developed economies. Canadian banks are also more profitable than those in other developed economies (Exhibit 1). Likewise, Canada’s insurance revenue pool is large. With estimated revenues of $136 billion in 2022, it’s one of the world’s ten largest insurance markets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1474ee9-ba07-42ce-bdf6-70080baa0f44"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1474ee9-ba07-42ce-bdf6-70080baa0f44" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Global Insurance Pools; excludes reinsurance and international revenues.</span></span></span></a></span> These attributes make Canada a tempting target for fintech attackers.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The Canadian banking industry is large and pro­fitable." src="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>Second, the Canadian financial-services industry is highly concentrated—often a sign that innovators are itching to shake things up. As of 2022, the top five banks generated more than three-quarters of banking revenue, while the top six insurance firms generated almost 50 percent of revenues in the sector.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fd57f2b8-fe9e-4551-aae3-4ecd033d93f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fd57f2b8-fe9e-4551-aae3-4ecd033d93f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey analysis of data from the following sources: annual reports from the Royal Bank of Canada (RBC), Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce (CICB), Toronto-Dominion Bank (TD), Scotiabank, and BMO Bank, accessed on the website for the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions; MSA Research; S&P Capital IQ; and McKinsey Global Insurance Pools.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Third, Canada ranks among the world’s top five countries for smartphone penetration, internet usage, and higher education levels—measures that suggest a readiness to embrace new technology.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="76b2f6ba-3f84-45dc-81ba-e4a00d819615"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="76b2f6ba-3f84-45dc-81ba-e4a00d819615" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Asli Demirgüç-Kunt, Leora Klapper, Dorothe Singer, and Saniya Ansar, <em>The Global Findex Database 2021: Financial inclusion, digital payments, and resilience in the age of COVID-19</em>, World Bank Group, 2022; McKinsey Panorama Global Banking Pools.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Yet Canada has not followed the textbook as fintech has grown in other developed countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2e30784d-104b-4a75-816a-d0674c486468"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2e30784d-104b-4a75-816a-d0674c486468" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">Fintechs: A new paradigm of growth</a>,” McKinsey, October 24, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Australia, for example—a country with a similar concentration of large financial-service providers—had grown to become the world’s sixth largest fintech market by 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1b7a842-8a6c-44cc-bd73-9d9876cda675"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1b7a842-8a6c-44cc-bd73-9d9876cda675" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“The Australian fintech export frenzy,” Australia Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, February 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> However, Canada has not been able to match Australia’s growth. Canada ranks among the bottom five developed countries for adoption of digital banking, digital B2B services, and fintech solutions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="73cc474e-a641-40b0-a0fb-95b7c112ac4b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="73cc474e-a641-40b0-a0fb-95b7c112ac4b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The Global Findex Database 2021, 2022</em>; McKinsey Panorama Global Banking Pools.</span></span></span></a></span> Only 13 percent of Canadian banking consumers use fintechs, for example, compared with 32 percent of those in the United Kingdom and 42 percent in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c2c0569b-a4e6-4456-8b18-803e57fcc3d6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c2c0569b-a4e6-4456-8b18-803e57fcc3d6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Retail Banking Consumer Survey, 2023, n = 2,012.</span></span></span></a></span> That leaves huge untapped potential. Canadian banking revenues from retail and small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs), for example, reached $135 billion in 2022, of which just 3 percent went to fintech. That’s about $5 billion short of what might be possible were penetration levels similar to those in the United States, where fintech penetration is 8 percent (Exhibit 2).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Fintech accounts for a lower percentage of banking revenues in Canada than in other markets." src="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<p>That’s not to detract from the progress made by some fintech players in certain segments of the Canadian market, particularly wealth management and payments. Wealthsimple, an online investment management service, had assets under management worth $30 billion by 2024, for example, while payments processor Nuvei, which completed an IPO in 2020, processed payments worth $141 billion and generated revenues of $870 million in the first nine months of 2023.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="01b321df-e1df-46f7-8baf-d21650cec8c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="01b321df-e1df-46f7-8baf-d21650cec8c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rob Carrick, “Wealthsimple is starting to look like Canada’s next big bank,” <em>Globe and Mail</em>, January 11, 2024; “Nuvei announces third quarter 2023 results,” Nuvei, November 7, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Some fintech infrastructure companies are also emerging—and their success will be key to the growth of fintech as they build the infrastructure and systems upon which digital financial-service offerings depend. Neo Financial is one such company, offering consumer-facing products as well as infrastructure services for payments, cards, and digital accounts. In 2023, Tim Hortons, a large Canadian restaurant chain, selected Neo to power its new credit card offering.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="752ac177-3267-4452-9132-e100ec0e945f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="752ac177-3267-4452-9132-e100ec0e945f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Tim Hortons selects Neo Financial to power its launch into financial services with the Tims Credit Card,” Business Wire, July 26, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The question therefore becomes what it will take to build on this momentum and for Canada’s fintech industry to fully bloom. To find out, we interviewed more than 40 leaders in the Canadian financial services industry, including investors and academics as well as leaders working for fintechs, incumbents, and lobby groups. The research points to five areas where developments will be critical to the long-term growth of the industry: consumer behavior, partnerships, funding, the regulatory environment, and talent.</p>

<h2>Consumer behavior</h2>

<p>It’s hard to persuade Canadian consumers to switch financial-service providers. Take retail banking, which, according to McKinsey analysis, accounts for more than 60 percent of banking revenues.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e5ebe00d-621e-4e24-8229-ce896d039974"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e5ebe00d-621e-4e24-8229-ce896d039974" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Panorama Global Banking Pools.</span></span></span></a></span> Our 2023 McKinsey Retail Banking Consumer Survey showed that 61 percent of respondents had used the same bank for ten years or more and that the number who might be inclined to switch banks had fallen, from 10 percent in 2021 to 9 percent in 2023. It’s hardly surprising, then, that 40 percent of the fintech leaders we interviewed highlighted difficulties attracting Canadian consumers to their platforms.</p>

<p>Consumers’ reluctance to switch might be explained by the fact that they are comparatively satisfied with their banks. Canadian banks’ customer satisfaction score—a measure of how likely consumers are to recommend their bank to others—has fallen of late, but it is still considerably higher than that of banks in Europe, where millions of people have switched to digital providers (Exhibit 3). Canadians are also reluctant to switch providers because of the difficult and time-consuming process involved. For example, consumers have to create a list of all their accounts and automatic payments and update this information with the new bank.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Canadian bank customers are more likely to recommend their bank than European customers are." src="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>The road ahead</h3>

<p>The key to attracting consumers can be to focus on the right ones, seeking to gain share in niche segments that are not well served by traditional financial institutions. One UK fintech was able to capture market share from large incumbents by targeting tech-savvy millennials and Gen Zers who were won over by the promise of a flawless digital experience that gave them 24/7 access to their finances globally—something traditional banks were unable to offer at the time.</p>

<p>In Canada, one niche segment might lie with people who have recently settled in the country. Canada has one of the world’s highest immigration rates and welcomed about 500,000 people in 2022. Of these, 60 percent were between 20 and 39 years old—the age group more likely to use fintech products.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c3edd773-8a68-4eaa-a6fc-8a73c69030be"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c3edd773-8a68-4eaa-a6fc-8a73c69030be" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Estimates of the components of international migration, by age and gender, annual,” Statistics Canada, February 21, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Many immigrants also come from Europe and countries such as China and India, where digital banking is more common, so they may be more open to using innovative banking offerings than many Canadians. As one fintech leader pointed out, “In other countries with more digitization, people no longer use cheques. Here, we still have huge volumes of them.” (In 2023, 28 percent of total Canadian payments values were classified as paper-initiated payment items, such as cheques.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="85e81819-a92a-4672-9d74-4c02a819bd65"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="85e81819-a92a-4672-9d74-4c02a819bd65" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Automated Clearing Settlement System statistics,” Payments Canada, January 3, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span>)</p>

<p>Fintechs might also find success in offering financial services that often are not available to new immigrants, such as credit facilities, or setting up an onboarding process that makes it easier for those who are new to the country to open an account. Lack of an established credit record or address can complicate newcomers’ access to financial services.</p>

<p>With the right products, opportunities might also lie with incumbents’ traditional consumers. Canada has a high rate of financial inclusion—about 98 percent as of 2021<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="73da6983-2783-4479-a1a4-4d1b6ae9f59b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="73da6983-2783-4479-a1a4-4d1b6ae9f59b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Redefining financial inclusion for a digital age: Implications for a central bank digital currency,” Bank of Canada, October 4, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span>—leaving next to no room for fintechs to build a consumer base by targeting entirely new retail-banking consumers. But they can offer bank consumers new services. For example, our analysis shows that more than 20 percent of retail banking revenues derive from people with middle to low incomes in the 18–44 age bracket, the majority of whom subscribe to very few banking services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ad12f51f-72f5-4e03-893a-3c5b9abd79d0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ad12f51f-72f5-4e03-893a-3c5b9abd79d0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Global Banking Pools Cube.</span></span></span></a></span> “The issue is not that people in Canada are unbanked; it’s that they are underbanked,” said one fintech leader. Many of these bank customers might be attracted by a fintech solution that helps them track and manage their spending, for example.</p>

<h2>Partnerships with incumbents</h2>

<p>Most incumbents once viewed fintechs as a threat. Today, however, partnerships between the two parties are more often seen as mutually beneficial and have thus become common in many developed markets. By 2021, incumbents in the United States each had an average 2.5 fintech partnerships, compared with 1.3 in 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45dc60c5-af16-49f3-9c70-71691352a2a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45dc60c5-af16-49f3-9c70-71691352a2a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“The state of the union in bank-fintech partnerships,” Synctera, January 10, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In Canada, partnerships remain scarce. Some credit unions and small and medium-size banks are working with fintechs—ATB Financial<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1654e613-e6ae-4522-859b-5856bc56b36a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1654e613-e6ae-4522-859b-5856bc56b36a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Knowlton Thomas, “Flinks and Oliu partner to enhance fintech experience in Canada,” Fintech.ca, January 16, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> and Equitable Bank are two examples.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a6affab2-d6e7-4fd8-9c06-871c71239ed3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a6affab2-d6e7-4fd8-9c06-871c71239ed3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“EQ Bank partners with Flinks to deliver on open banking,” Equitable Bank, July 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> But 68 percent of the fintech leaders, investors, and academics we interviewed identified challenges associated with bank–fintech partnerships. These included long sales cycles of up to 24 months, costly and arduous risk management and compliance requirements, and stringent exclusivity clauses. “In the United States, banks are way more willing to partner with fintechs and use them as a consumer acquisition channel,” remarked one fintech leader.</p>

<p>Incumbents also say that regulatory compliance requirements hamper the formation of partnerships. And some feel that partnerships formed to date have been disappointing, often proving to be no more than standard vendor relationships. They also say there is a shortage of world-class Canadian fintechs with which to partner.</p>

<h3>The road ahead</h3>

<p>The key to more partnerships will be greater awareness of the benefits. Incumbents should also make sure they do not overlook local partnership opportunities because of a perceived need for global partners. There are two main types of partnerships. The first is a fintech enabler model, whereby incumbents harness a fintech’s innovation and agility to optimize their own internal processes, adopting proven technologies and business models (and sometimes consumer bases). Cost savings are also possible. The second is an infrastructure provider model, whereby fintechs leverage parts of the incumbent’s technological infrastructure, including licenses and payments infrastructure, thereby reducing the cost and time associated with going to market with their own products.</p>

<p>In both models, the partners share the risks and rewards and ultimately help grow the financial services sector by giving consumers more providers from which to choose and products that are more sophisticated. Tink, a European cloud-based platform, is an example of the enabler model. Through its partnerships with more than 6,000 financial institutions, Tink has built an open-banking platform that connects financial-services providers to consumers’ bank data, helping providers make fast onboarding assessments and attract and engage consumers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a325f5e6-2aaf-4305-a488-fe53058303ea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a325f5e6-2aaf-4305-a488-fe53058303ea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“About us,” Tink, accessed March 20, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Growth of the fintech sector inevitably depends upon the availability of capital to support growing companies.</p></blockquote></div>

<h2>Funding</h2>

<p>Growth of the fintech sector inevitably depends upon the availability of capital to support growing companies. And while there is no shortage of Canadian venture capital (VC), the US fintech market remains a primary target for investors due to its larger size and maturity. Fifty percent of the investors we interviewed said they also invested in US fintechs. VC funding tends to work well in markets with technology clusters such as Silicon Valley—something that is lacking in the Canadian fintech ecosystem.</p>

<p>The funding figures reflect the draw of bigger, more mature markets. Between 2017 and 2023, VC funding for Canadian fintechs grew at 1.8 percent per year, on average, compared with 18 percent in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8f7c2cb5-7a32-40e8-b90c-4d0becd99033"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8f7c2cb5-7a32-40e8-b90c-4d0becd99033" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey analysis of PitchBook deal status data, November 28, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Today, Canadian funding for fintech as a percentage of banking revenues is similar to that in Australia, compared with larger mature markets such as the United Kingdom and the United States, and 60 percent of the fintech leaders we interviewed said they had encountered challenges securing local funding (Exhibit 4).</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Bigger, more mature fintech markets attract more funding than Canada relative to banking revenues." src="/ca/~/media/mckinsey/locations/north%20america/canada/our%20insights/springtime%20for%20canadas%20fintech%20industry/svgz_mck_canadianfintech_exs_exh4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>

<h3>The road ahead</h3>

<p>More investors may come forward as economic conditions ease and interest rates fall. When they do, our analysis suggests it will be important to spread funding more evenly across maturities to boost the sector’s growth. Between 2018 and 2023, funding for late-stage firms grew at 13 percent per year, while midstage funding fell by about 23 percent and early-stage seed funding stagnated.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="60a7b2a8-34f6-4491-8bac-c11c28bb86be"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="60a7b2a8-34f6-4491-8bac-c11c28bb86be" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on McKinsey analysis of PitchBook deal status data, November 28, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Without more early- and midstage funding, it will be hard to support more growth in the sector.</p>

<p>Earlier-stage funding is likely to grow alongside investor confidence as more fintechs grow and complete successful exits, joining the ranks of Verafin, a Canada-based regulatory technology company that was sold for $2.75 billion in 2021.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="54b23a15-5247-43be-976d-4d0a43fee9dc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="54b23a15-5247-43be-976d-4d0a43fee9dc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Nasdaq to acquire Verafin, creating a global leader in the fight against financial crime,” Verafin, November 19, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, the founders of successful buyouts may well become angel investors in new start-ups. Executives at PayPal, bought by eBay in 2002, went on to fund other start-ups in Silicon Valley, including Affirm, Facebook, Stripe, Square, and YouTube.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="054261b7-3974-470c-9b94-afd0ab2e8151"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="054261b7-3974-470c-9b94-afd0ab2e8151" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew Granato and Scy Yoon, “A look at the PayPal Mafia’s continued impact on Silicon Valley,” VentureBeat, January 13, 2019; Tami Brehse and Kylie Kirschner, “Members of the PayPal Mafia include tech titans like Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, and Reid Hoffman. Here’s where they are now,” Business Insider, November 12, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> And executives at Canadian software company Research In Motion, the creators of the BlackBerry cell phone, have invested in other businesses in Canada’s high-tech cluster in the Waterloo region.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95069900-beec-4f08-9376-ea4e998fbeaa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95069900-beec-4f08-9376-ea4e998fbeaa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sam Byford, “BlackBerry founder hopes to achieve ‘Star Trek’ future with $100 million quantum tech fund,” The Verge, March 19, 2013.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Funding for B2B fintech solutions will likely spur growth of the sector. Infrastructure solutions, for example, will not only support the entire fintech ecosystem but could also give fintechs a competitive edge over incumbents whose legacy infrastructure can be slow, inflexible, and costly. “Traditional infrastructure in financial services today is relatively outdated and archaic,” said one interviewee.</p>

<p>Funding for fintech solutions for SMEs could also propel growth; SMEs have long been underserved by traditional financial-services providers in markets around the world, despite the fact they represent about 90 percent of businesses, according to McKinsey research.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4fafe61-2119-4aa5-b6a8-2c46015f9585"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4fafe61-2119-4aa5-b6a8-2c46015f9585" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/fintechs-a-new-paradigm-of-growth">Fintechs</a>,” October 24, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The Canadian market is no different.</p>

<p>Much depends on fintechs themselves if more funding is to materialize, however. Investors are more likely to back companies that create disruptive products and valuable intellectual property that prove competitive on a world stage. Yet more than 30 percent of the investors interviewed said lack of innovation was one reason for not funding more Canadian fintechs. They felt there were too many “me too” products and solutions.</p>

<h2>The regulatory environment</h2>

<p>Regulatory developments will play a key role in the growth of fintech in Canada. In some markets where fintech has become established, regulators have encouraged new market entrants by, for example, creating tiered licensing regimes that align with the risk of their offerings and introducing what are regarded as innovation-friendly regulations that facilitate real-time payments systems and open banking. Open banking permits third parties to access consumers’ financial data with their consent, making it possible to identify suitable product offerings, for example, or to help consumers easily switch their checking account to a different bank.</p>

<p>Regulators of the Canadian financial system, which has long been a global model of stability and security, have been more cautious. Canada is, for example, one of the few OECD markets without a defined open banking regulatory framework.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be187be4-9aa0-463c-a4e6-1d730095fa7c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be187be4-9aa0-463c-a4e6-1d730095fa7c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Shifting from open banking to open finance: Results from the 2022 OECD survey on data sharing frameworks</em>, OECD, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Many interviewees said they are challenged with navigating the country’s regulatory stance as they identify opportunities for innovation and growth.</p>

<h3>The road ahead</h3>

<p>The regulatory environment may be changing. In December 2023, the federal government began a consultation process to consider measures it could potentially take to strengthen competition in the financial sector, including measures that might support fintechs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a52f6b5e-f5d1-49c5-a2af-c3e05a3bfe51"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a52f6b5e-f5d1-49c5-a2af-c3e05a3bfe51" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Consultation on strengthening competition in the financial sector,” Government of Canada, updated March 4, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> It has also announced its intention to introduce the budget for open banking framework legislation in 2024,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="701ab651-a7bc-4ebf-afb8-df09df2d0ff6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="701ab651-a7bc-4ebf-afb8-df09df2d0ff6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“2023 fall economic statements: Policy statement on consumer-driven banking,” Government of Canada, November 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> and it is working to establish a real-time payments system. These changes could help unlock faster growth in the sector, increase competition, and reduce costs for consumers.</p>

<h2>Talent</h2>

<p>Innovation in a market is tied to the availability of talent, which in turn is bolstered by the quality of education. On this basis, Canada is set to support a thriving fintech ecosystem. It boasts an excellent educational system that produces a high percentage of STEM graduates relative to the population. In 2020, 24 percent of Canadians were STEM graduates, compared with 18 percent in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="87278f18-a4fd-4bc6-9e9d-20ec7cd7906a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="87278f18-a4fd-4bc6-9e9d-20ec7cd7906a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“2020/2021 postsecondary graduates, by International Standard Classification of Education, institution type, Classification of Instructional Programs, STEM and BHASE groupings, status of student in Canada, age group and gender,” Statistics Canada, November 22, 2023; McKinsey analysis of 2020–21 US data from National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) tables 321.10 (Associate’s), 322.10 (Bachelor’s), 323.10 (Master’s), and 324.10 (Doctorates), using the International Standard Classification of Education’s (ISCED) definition of STEM.</span></span></span></a></span> The nation’s digital skills are growing quickly, too. In 2022, Calgary, Toronto, and Vancouver saw digital skills growth of 6.3 percent, surpassing New York City, San Francisco, and Seattle, where growth averaged about 4.7 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f15c26c8-1409-48d8-afb8-c125d51d9c9d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f15c26c8-1409-48d8-afb8-c125d51d9c9d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Stem talent: Canada’s shift from brain drain to brain gain,” Invest Canada, April 21, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In addition, immigrants to Canada tend to attain higher education. As of 2023, 68 percent of landed immigrants had attained postsecondary certificates or university degrees.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0576bed4-d7c9-469d-8fb7-fa90da73f3ab"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0576bed4-d7c9-469d-8fb7-fa90da73f3ab" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Labour force characteristics of immigrants by educational attainment, annual,” Statistics Canada, January 5, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Canada’s education system and its number of highly educated immigrants help explain why the country has been at the forefront of important innovations in recent years. Companies operating in Toronto and Montréal have been instrumental in the development of AI, for example.</p>

<p>A hurdle to cross in fintech, however, is a lack of more experienced talent in the sector. Some interviewees said that while junior positions could be filled, it was harder to find senior people with the experience of growing a start-up—people who had “seen the show before,” as one interviewee put it. “We’re trying to go from the start-up to the scale-up stage, and it is hard to find executive-level talent that has seen the show repeatedly and experienced growing a company from 20 to 50 to 1,000 consumers. It seems the talent pool is shrinking as we get bigger,” one interviewee told us. Twenty-nine percent of fintech leaders surveyed said they had found it hard to recruit local experienced talent.</p>

<h3>The road ahead</h3>

<p>The challenge of finding experienced talent will likely ease as the ecosystem matures. And just as the founders of companies that have made successful exits might finance more fintech start-ups in Canada, so too could founders help promote start-ups’ growth by acting as advisers.</p>

<p>The government may also consider attracting experienced fintech talent to Canada by further promoting existing initiatives and programs intended to encourage entrepreneurs and investors elsewhere to establish a presence in Canada.</p>

<hr>

<p>The Canadian fintech sector appears set for growth. The right product offerings are likely to attract Canada’s many digitally savvy consumers who are open to innovation. Improved financial conditions will likely see more funding for fintechs—funding that could prove particularly powerful if spread more evenly across maturity stages and focused more on B2B solutions. Partnerships between incumbents and fintechs have the potential to benefit both parties. There are signs of change on the regulatory front, and there is an abundance of talent to help develop new products.</p>

<p>Nevertheless, it is hard to say just when the Canadian fintech industry will come into full bloom, given that it depends on progress in all the areas discussed. Moreover, it’s unlikely that progress will be spread evenly across the industry. Some categories might rapidly offer tremendous opportunities, while others might stall, whether that’s due to global trends or the peculiarities of the Canadian market. Fintechs, incumbents, and investors will therefore need to place their bets with extreme care. But it remains that the sector has large untapped opportunities that interested players should prepare to grasp.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/federico-berruti">Federico Berruti</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Toronto office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/uzayr-jeenah">Uzayr Jeenah</a></strong> is a partner, <strong>Opeyemi Otubela</strong> is a consultant, and <strong>Emily Seng Yue</strong> is an associate partner; <strong><a href="/our-people/miklos-dietz">Miklós Dietz</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Vancouver office; and <strong>Ammar Zahid</strong> is an associate partner in the Miami office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Daniel Arguedas, Chloe Chan, Soma Cserhati, Jay Datesh, Evan Formisano, Janae Knott, Audrey Liang, Farid Minnikhanov, and Nemanja Predojevic for their contributions to this report.</p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Springtime for Canadas fintech industry","displayName":"Springtime for Canadas fintech industry","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"ca1a1226-be6c-4d3f-a3a7-e21061078cce","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Springtime for Canada\u0026rsquo;s fintech industry?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Fintech companies in Canada: Is the industry ready to boom?"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The uptake of digital financial services is low in Canada compared with other similar economies. Developments in five areas will determine if the industry is about to blossom."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Fintech companies in Canada have made marked progress in areas such as wealth management and payments. Five areas are key to long term growth in the industry."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-04-16T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCanada\u0026rsquo;s financial-services industry\u003c/strong\u003e seems to be a textbook case of an industry primed for disruption by fintech.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, its banking industry is large compared with other G-7 countries. Banking revenues of $180 billion accounted for 7.9 percent of GDP in 2023, compared with 5.8 percent in the United States and an average of 5.6 percent among other developed economies. Canadian banks are also more profitable than those in other developed economies (Exhibit 1). Likewise, Canada\u0026rsquo;s insurance revenue pool is large. With estimated revenues of $136 billion in 2022, it\u0026rsquo;s one of the world\u0026rsquo;s ten largest insurance markets.[[footnote 1]] These attributes make Canada a tempting target for fintech attackers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, the Canadian financial-services industry is highly concentrated\u0026mdash;often a sign that innovators are itching to shake things up. As of 2022, the top five banks generated more than three-quarters of banking revenue, while the top six insurance firms generated almost 50 percent of revenues in the sector.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThird, Canada ranks among the world\u0026rsquo;s top five countries for smartphone penetration, internet usage, and higher education levels\u0026mdash;measures that suggest a readiness to embrace new technology.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eYet Canada has not followed the textbook as fintech has grown in other developed countries.[[footnote 4]] Australia, for example\u0026mdash;a country with a similar concentration of large financial-service providers\u0026mdash;had grown to become the world\u0026rsquo;s sixth largest fintech market by 2022.[[footnote 5]] However, Canada has not been able to match Australia\u0026rsquo;s growth. Canada ranks among the bottom five developed countries for adoption of digital banking, digital B2B services, and fintech solutions.[[footnote 6]] Only 13 percent of Canadian banking consumers use fintechs, for example, compared with 32 percent of those in the United Kingdom and 42 percent in the United States.[[footnote 7]] That leaves huge untapped potential. Canadian banking revenues from retail and small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs), for example, reached $135 billion in 2022, of which just 3 percent went to fintech. That\u0026rsquo;s about $5 billion short of what might be possible were penetration levels similar to those in the United States, where fintech penetration is 8 percent (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s not to detract from the progress made by some fintech players in certain segments of the Canadian market, particularly wealth management and payments. Wealthsimple, an online investment management service, had assets under management worth $30 billion by 2024, for example, while payments processor Nuvei, which completed an IPO in 2020, processed payments worth $141 billion and generated revenues of $870 million in the first nine months of 2023.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSome fintech infrastructure companies are also emerging\u0026mdash;and their success will be key to the growth of fintech as they build the infrastructure and systems upon which digital financial-service offerings depend. Neo Financial is one such company, offering consumer-facing products as well as infrastructure services for payments, cards, and digital accounts. In 2023, Tim Hortons, a large Canadian restaurant chain, selected Neo to power its new credit card offering.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe question therefore becomes what it will take to build on this momentum and for Canada\u0026rsquo;s fintech industry to fully bloom. To find out, we interviewed more than 40 leaders in the Canadian financial services industry, including investors and academics as well as leaders working for fintechs, incumbents, and lobby groups. The research points to five areas where developments will be critical to the long-term growth of the industry: consumer behavior, partnerships, funding, the regulatory environment, and talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eConsumer behavior\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s hard to persuade Canadian consumers to switch financial-service providers. Take retail banking, which, according to McKinsey analysis, accounts for more than 60 percent of banking revenues.[[footnote 10]] Our 2023 McKinsey Retail Banking Consumer Survey showed that 61 percent of respondents had used the same bank for ten years or more and that the number who might be inclined to switch banks had fallen, from 10 percent in 2021 to 9 percent in 2023. It\u0026rsquo;s hardly surprising, then, that 40 percent of the fintech leaders we interviewed highlighted difficulties attracting Canadian consumers to their platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eConsumers\u0026rsquo; reluctance to switch might be explained by the fact that they are comparatively satisfied with their banks. Canadian banks\u0026rsquo; customer satisfaction score\u0026mdash;a measure of how likely consumers are to recommend their bank to others\u0026mdash;has fallen of late, but it is still considerably higher than that of banks in Europe, where millions of people have switched to digital providers (Exhibit 3). Canadians are also reluctant to switch providers because of the difficult and time-consuming process involved. For example, consumers have to create a list of all their accounts and automatic payments and update this information with the new bank.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 3]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eThe road ahead\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe key to attracting consumers can be to focus on the right ones, seeking to gain share in niche segments that are not well served by traditional financial institutions. One UK fintech was able to capture market share from large incumbents by targeting tech-savvy millennials and Gen Zers who were won over by the promise of a flawless digital experience that gave them 24/7 access to their finances globally\u0026mdash;something traditional banks were unable to offer at the time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn Canada, one niche segment might lie with people who have recently settled in the country. Canada has one of the world\u0026rsquo;s highest immigration rates and welcomed about 500,000 people in 2022. Of these, 60 percent were between 20 and 39 years old\u0026mdash;the age group more likely to use fintech products.[[footnote 11]] Many immigrants also come from Europe and countries such as China and India, where digital banking is more common, so they may be more open to using innovative banking offerings than many Canadians. As one fintech leader pointed out, \u0026ldquo;In other countries with more digitization, people no longer use cheques. Here, we still have huge volumes of them.\u0026rdquo; (In 2023, 28 percent of total Canadian payments values were classified as paper-initiated payment items, such as cheques.[[footnote 12]])\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFintechs might also find success in offering financial services that often are not available to new immigrants, such as credit facilities, or setting up an onboarding process that makes it easier for those who are new to the country to open an account. Lack of an established credit record or address can complicate newcomers\u0026rsquo; access to financial services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWith the right products, opportunities might also lie with incumbents\u0026rsquo; traditional consumers. Canada has a high rate of financial inclusion\u0026mdash;about 98 percent as of 2021[[footnote 13]]\u0026mdash;leaving next to no room for fintechs to build a consumer base by targeting entirely new retail-banking consumers. But they can offer bank consumers new services. For example, our analysis shows that more than 20 percent of retail banking revenues derive from people with middle to low incomes in the 18\u0026ndash;44 age bracket, the majority of whom subscribe to very few banking services.[[footnote 14]] \u0026ldquo;The issue is not that people in Canada are unbanked; it\u0026rsquo;s that they are underbanked,\u0026rdquo; said one fintech leader. Many of these bank customers might be attracted by a fintech solution that helps them track and manage their spending, for example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003ePartnerships with incumbents\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMost incumbents once viewed fintechs as a threat. Today, however, partnerships between the two parties are more often seen as mutually beneficial and have thus become common in many developed markets. By 2021, incumbents in the United States each had an average 2.5 fintech partnerships, compared with 1.3 in 2019.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn Canada, partnerships remain scarce. Some credit unions and small and medium-size banks are working with fintechs\u0026mdash;ATB Financial[[footnote 16]] and Equitable Bank are two examples.[[footnote 17]] But 68 percent of the fintech leaders, investors, and academics we interviewed identified challenges associated with bank\u0026ndash;fintech partnerships. These included long sales cycles of up to 24 months, costly and arduous risk management and compliance requirements, and stringent exclusivity clauses. \u0026ldquo;In the United States, banks are way more willing to partner with fintechs and use them as a consumer acquisition channel,\u0026rdquo; remarked one fintech leader.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIncumbents also say that regulatory compliance requirements hamper the formation of partnerships. And some feel that partnerships formed to date have been disappointing, often proving to be no more than standard vendor relationships. They also say there is a shortage of world-class Canadian fintechs with which to partner.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eThe road ahead\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe key to more partnerships will be greater awareness of the benefits. Incumbents should also make sure they do not overlook local partnership opportunities because of a perceived need for global partners. There are two main types of partnerships. The first is a fintech enabler model, whereby incumbents harness a fintech\u0026rsquo;s innovation and agility to optimize their own internal processes, adopting proven technologies and business models (and sometimes consumer bases). Cost savings are also possible. The second is an infrastructure provider model, whereby fintechs leverage parts of the incumbent\u0026rsquo;s technological infrastructure, including licenses and payments infrastructure, thereby reducing the cost and time associated with going to market with their own products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn both models, the partners share the risks and rewards and ultimately help grow the financial services sector by giving consumers more providers from which to choose and products that are more sophisticated. Tink, a European cloud-based platform, is an example of the enabler model. Through its partnerships with more than 6,000 financial institutions, Tink has built an open-banking platform that connects financial-services providers to consumers\u0026rsquo; bank data, helping providers make fast onboarding assessments and attract and engage consumers.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[pullquote 1]]\n\n\u003ch2\u003eFunding\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eGrowth of the fintech sector inevitably depends upon the availability of capital to support growing companies. And while there is no shortage of Canadian venture capital (VC), the US fintech market remains a primary target for investors due to its larger size and maturity. Fifty percent of the investors we interviewed said they also invested in US fintechs. VC funding tends to work well in markets with technology clusters such as Silicon Valley\u0026mdash;something that is lacking in the Canadian fintech ecosystem.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe funding figures reflect the draw of bigger, more mature markets. Between 2017 and 2023, VC funding for Canadian fintechs grew at 1.8 percent per year, on average, compared with 18 percent in the United States.[[footnote 19]] Today, Canadian funding for fintech as a percentage of banking revenues is similar to that in Australia, compared with larger mature markets such as the United Kingdom and the United States, and 60 percent of the fintech leaders we interviewed said they had encountered challenges securing local funding (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[exhibit 4]]\n\n\u003ch3\u003eThe road ahead\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMore investors may come forward as economic conditions ease and interest rates fall. When they do, our analysis suggests it will be important to spread funding more evenly across maturities to boost the sector\u0026rsquo;s growth. Between 2018 and 2023, funding for late-stage firms grew at 13 percent per year, while midstage funding fell by about 23 percent and early-stage seed funding stagnated.[[footnote 20]] Without more early- and midstage funding, it will be hard to support more growth in the sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eEarlier-stage funding is likely to grow alongside investor confidence as more fintechs grow and complete successful exits, joining the ranks of Verafin, a Canada-based regulatory technology company that was sold for $2.75 billion in 2021.[[footnote 21]] In addition, the founders of successful buyouts may well become angel investors in new start-ups. Executives at PayPal, bought by eBay in 2002, went on to fund other start-ups in Silicon Valley, including Affirm, Facebook, Stripe, Square, and YouTube.[[footnote 22]] And executives at Canadian software company Research In Motion, the creators of the BlackBerry cell phone, have invested in other businesses in Canada\u0026rsquo;s high-tech cluster in the Waterloo region.[[footnote 23]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFunding for B2B fintech solutions will likely spur growth of the sector. Infrastructure solutions, for example, will not only support the entire fintech ecosystem but could also give fintechs a competitive edge over incumbents whose legacy infrastructure can be slow, inflexible, and costly. \u0026ldquo;Traditional infrastructure in financial services today is relatively outdated and archaic,\u0026rdquo; said one interviewee.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFunding for fintech solutions for SMEs could also propel growth; SMEs have long been underserved by traditional financial-services providers in markets around the world, despite the fact they represent about 90 percent of businesses, according to McKinsey research.[[footnote 24]] The Canadian market is no different.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eMuch depends on fintechs themselves if more funding is to materialize, however. Investors are more likely to back companies that create disruptive products and valuable intellectual property that prove competitive on a world stage. Yet more than 30 percent of the investors interviewed said lack of innovation was one reason for not funding more Canadian fintechs. They felt there were too many \u0026ldquo;me too\u0026rdquo; products and solutions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eThe regulatory environment\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRegulatory developments will play a key role in the growth of fintech in Canada. In some markets where fintech has become established, regulators have encouraged new market entrants by, for example, creating tiered licensing regimes that align with the risk of their offerings and introducing what are regarded as innovation-friendly regulations that facilitate real-time payments systems and open banking. Open banking permits third parties to access consumers\u0026rsquo; financial data with their consent, making it possible to identify suitable product offerings, for example, or to help consumers easily switch their checking account to a different bank.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eRegulators of the Canadian financial system, which has long been a global model of stability and security, have been more cautious. Canada is, for example, one of the few OECD markets without a defined open banking regulatory framework.[[footnote 25]] Many interviewees said they are challenged with navigating the country\u0026rsquo;s regulatory stance as they identify opportunities for innovation and growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eThe road ahead\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe regulatory environment may be changing. In December 2023, the federal government began a consultation process to consider measures it could potentially take to strengthen competition in the financial sector, including measures that might support fintechs.[[footnote 26]] It has also announced its intention to introduce the budget for open banking framework legislation in 2024,[[footnote 27]] and it is working to establish a real-time payments system. These changes could help unlock faster growth in the sector, increase competition, and reduce costs for consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eTalent\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eInnovation in a market is tied to the availability of talent, which in turn is bolstered by the quality of education. On this basis, Canada is set to support a thriving fintech ecosystem. It boasts an excellent educational system that produces a high percentage of STEM graduates relative to the population. In 2020, 24 percent of Canadians were STEM graduates, compared with 18 percent in the United States.[[footnote 28]] The nation\u0026rsquo;s digital skills are growing quickly, too. In 2022, Calgary, Toronto, and Vancouver saw digital skills growth of 6.3 percent, surpassing New York City, San Francisco, and Seattle, where growth averaged about 4.7 percent.[[footnote 29]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, immigrants to Canada tend to attain higher education. As of 2023, 68 percent of landed immigrants had attained postsecondary certificates or university degrees.[[footnote 30]] Canada\u0026rsquo;s education system and its number of highly educated immigrants help explain why the country has been at the forefront of important innovations in recent years. Companies operating in Toronto and Montr\u0026eacute;al have been instrumental in the development of AI, for example.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eA hurdle to cross in fintech, however, is a lack of more experienced talent in the sector. Some interviewees said that while junior positions could be filled, it was harder to find senior people with the experience of growing a start-up\u0026mdash;people who had \u0026ldquo;seen the show before,\u0026rdquo; as one interviewee put it. \u0026ldquo;We\u0026rsquo;re trying to go from the start-up to the scale-up stage, and it is hard to find executive-level talent that has seen the show repeatedly and experienced growing a company from 20 to 50 to 1,000 consumers. It seems the talent pool is shrinking as we get bigger,\u0026rdquo; one interviewee told us. Twenty-nine percent of fintech leaders surveyed said they had found it hard to recruit local experienced talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eThe road ahead\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe challenge of finding experienced talent will likely ease as the ecosystem matures. And just as the founders of companies that have made successful exits might finance more fintech start-ups in Canada, so too could founders help promote start-ups\u0026rsquo; growth by acting as advisers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe government may also consider attracting experienced fintech talent to Canada by further promoting existing initiatives and programs intended to encourage entrepreneurs and investors elsewhere to establish a presence in Canada.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe Canadian fintech sector appears set for growth. The right product offerings are likely to attract Canada\u0026rsquo;s many digitally savvy consumers who are open to innovation. Improved financial conditions will likely see more funding for fintechs\u0026mdash;funding that could prove particularly powerful if spread more evenly across maturity stages and focused more on B2B solutions. Partnerships between incumbents and fintechs have the potential to benefit both parties. There are signs of change on the regulatory front, and there is an abundance of talent to help develop new products.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eNevertheless, it is hard to say just when the Canadian fintech industry will come into full bloom, given that it depends on progress in all the areas discussed. Moreover, it\u0026rsquo;s unlikely that progress will be spread evenly across the industry. Some categories might rapidly offer tremendous opportunities, while others might stall, whether that\u0026rsquo;s due to global trends or the peculiarities of the Canadian market. Fintechs, incumbents, and investors will therefore need to place their bets with extreme care. But it remains that the sector has large untapped opportunities that interested players should prepare to grasp.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2024-04-16T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMcKinsey Global Insurance Pools;
